abstract: A protocol that mutable objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
overview:
## Overview

The [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying] protocol declares a method for providing mutable copies of an object. Only classes that define an “immutable vs. mutable” distinction should adopt this protocol. Classes that don’t define such a distinction should adopt [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] instead.

[doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying] declares one method, [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying/mutableCopy(with:)], but mutable copying is commonly invoked with the convenience method [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/mutableCopy()]. The [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/mutableCopy()] method is defined for all NSObjects and simply invokes [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying/mutableCopy(with:)] with the default zone.

If a subclass inherits [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying] from its superclass and declares additional instance variables, the subclass has to override [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying/mutableCopy(with:)] to properly handle its own instance variables, invoking the superclass’s implementation first.
rawMarkdown:
---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying
crawled: 2025-12-03T16:16:02Z
---

# NSMutableCopying

**Protocol**

A protocol that mutable objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.

## Declaration

```swift
protocol NSMutableCopying
```

## Overview

The [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying] protocol declares a method for providing mutable copies of an object. Only classes that define an “immutable vs. mutable” distinction should adopt this protocol. Classes that don’t define such a distinction should adopt [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] instead.

[doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying] declares one method, [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying/mutableCopy(with:)], but mutable copying is commonly invoked with the convenience method [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/mutableCopy()]. The [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/mutableCopy()] method is defined for all NSObjects and simply invokes [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying/mutableCopy(with:)] with the default zone.

If a subclass inherits [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying] from its superclass and declares additional instance variables, the subclass has to override [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMutableCopying/mutableCopy(with:)] to properly handle its own instance variables, invoking the superclass’s implementation first.

## Copying

- **mutableCopy(with:)**: Returns a new instance that’s a mutable copy of the receiver.

## Copying

- **NSCopying**: A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.

## Conforming Types

- NSArray
- NSAttributedString
- NSCharacterSet
- NSCountedSet
- NSData
- NSDictionary
- NSIndexSet
- NSMutableArray
- NSMutableAttributedString
- NSMutableCharacterSet
- NSMutableData
- NSMutableDictionary
- NSMutableIndexSet
- NSMutableOrderedSet
- NSMutableSet
- NSMutableString
- NSMutableURLRequest
- NSOrderedSet
- NSPurgeableData
- NSSet
- NSString
- NSURLRequest
